docs.title: Clout Cards Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the Clout Cards documentation! Clout Cards is a crypto poker platform that combines on-chain asset management with Twitter social identity.

docs.title: What is Clout Cards?
docs.text:
Clout Cards allows you to:

  • Play real poker with ETH deposits and wagers
  • Use your Twitter identity to represent you at the table
  • Deposit and withdraw funds through smart contracts on Base Sepolia
  • Chat with other players in real-time at your table

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• How To Play - Learn how to get started, deposit funds, join tables, and play poker.
  • Architecture - Understand the technical architecture including smart contracts, backend services, and real-time events.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Connect your wallet - Use MetaMask or another Web3 wallet
  2. Sign in with Twitter - Link your Twitter account for identity
  3. Deposit ETH - Fund your escrow balance via the smart contract
  4. Join a table - Pick a table and buy in with your escrow balance
  5. Play poker! - Standard Texas Hold'em rules apply

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: If you have questions or run into issues, reach out to the team on Twitter or check the GitHub repository.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: Clout Cards is built with a modern, secure architecture that combines on-chain asset management with off-chain game logic.

docs.title: Core Components
docs.text: Component Technology Purpose Smart Contracts Solidity Asset custody, deposits, withdrawals Backend Node.js, Express, Prisma Game logic, event signing, API Frontend React, TypeScript User interface, wallet integration Events PostgreSQL NOTIFY, SSE Real-time game updates

docs.title: 1. Trustless Asset Management
docs.text:
• All funds are held in smart contracts
  • Users maintain custody of their assets
  • Withdrawals require user signature

docs.title: 2. Signed Event Chain
docs.text:
• Every game action is signed by the server
  • Events are cryptographically verifiable
  • Full audit trail in the database

docs.title: 3. Real-time Updates
docs.text:
• Server-Sent Events (SSE) for live updates
  • PostgreSQL LISTEN/NOTIFY for efficient broadcasting
  • No polling required

docs.title: 4. Social Identity
docs.text:
• Twitter OAuth for identity
  • Profile pictures and handles displayed at tables
  • Social features (chat) tied to Twitter identity

docs.title: Data Flow
docs.text:
1. Deposits: User → Smart Contract → Backend listens → Updates balance
  2. Game Actions: User → Backend → Database + Event → SSE broadcast
  3. Withdrawals: User → Backend signs → User → Smart Contract

docs.title: Security Model
docs.text:
• Assets: Secured by smart contract (on-chain)
  • Game Logic: Server-side only (prevents cheating)
  • Identity: Twitter OAuth + wallet signature
  • Events: EIP-712 signed payloads

docs.title: Event Signing
docs.text:
All game events are signed using EIP-712:

  1. Event payload is serialized to JSON
  2. EIP-712 digest is computed
  3. Server signs with TEE private key
  4. Signature (r, s, v) is stored with event

This creates a verifiable audit trail of all game actions.

docs.text: Job Interval Purpose Action Timeout Checker 1.5s Auto-fold timed-out players Hand Start Checker 1.5s Start hands when ready Contract Listener Real-time Process on-chain events

docs.title: Real-time Events
docs.text: Clout Cards uses Server-Sent Events (SSE) with PostgreSQL LISTEN/NOTIFY for real-time updates.

docs.title: Why SSE?
docs.text:
Feature SSE WebSockets Direction Server → Client Bidirectional Complexity Simple More complex Reconnection Built-in Manual Use case Event streaming Chat, gaming

For poker, SSE is ideal: - Game actions sent via REST API - Updates streamed via SSE - No need for bidirectional communication

docs.title: Event Flow
docs.text:
1. Player makes action (REST API)
      ↓
2. Backend processes action
      ↓
3. Event created in database
      ↓
4. PostgreSQL TRIGGER fires
      ↓
5. pg_notify('new_event', payload)
      ↓
6. Backend receives notification
      ↓
7. SSE broadcasts to subscribers
      ↓
8. Frontend receives and processes

docs.title: Game Events (stored in DB)
docs.text: Event Description hand_start New hand begins, blinds posted hand_action Player action (fold/call/raise/etc) community_cards Flop/turn/river dealt hand_end Hand complete, winners announced join_table Player sits down leave_table Player stands up

docs.title: Ephemeral Events (in-memory only)
docs.text: Event Description chat_message Player chat message

docs.title: Event Payload Structure
docs.text:
All events follow this structure:

{
  "kind": "hand_action",
  "table": { "id": 1, "name": "Table 1" },
  "hand": { "id": 123, "round": "FLOP" },
  "action": {
    "type": "RAISE",
    "amount": "1000000000",
    "seatNumber": 3
  },
  "playerBalances": [
    { "seatNumber": 1, "tableBalanceGwei": "5000000000" },
    { "seatNumber": 3, "tableBalanceGwei": "4000000000" }
  ]
}

docs.title: SSE Endpoint
docs.text: GET /api/tables/:tableId/events?lastEventId=0

docs.title: Query Parameters
docs.text: Param Description lastEventId Resume from this event ID (for reconnection)

docs.title: Response Format
docs.text:
: connected

id: 1234
data: {"kind":"hand_start",...}

id: 1235
data: {"kind":"hand_action",...}

: heartbeat

docs.title: Event Queue
docs.text:
Events are processed sequentially to ensure correct ordering:

// utils/eventQueue.ts
class EventQueue {
  enqueue(event)     // Add to queue
  processQueue()     // Process one at a time
}

docs.title: Hook Usage
docs.text:
useTableEvents({
  tableId: 1,
  enabled: true,
  lastEventId: 0,
  onEvent: async (event) => {
    // Handle event
  }
});

docs.title: Reconnection
docs.text:
The frontend handles disconnections automatically:

  1. SSE connection drops
  2. Exponential backoff (1s, 2s, 4s, ... up to 5min)
  3. Reconnect with lastEventId to resume
  4. Missed events are sent immediately
  5. Continue streaming new events

docs.title: PostgreSQL Setup
docs.text:
-- Trigger function
CREATE FUNCTION notify_new_event() RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
BEGIN
  PERFORM pg_notify('new_event', json_build_object(
    'eventId', NEW.event_id,
    'tableId', NEW.table_id,
    'kind', NEW.kind
  )::text);
  RETURN NEW;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;

-- Trigger on events table
CREATE TRIGGER event_notify_trigger
  AFTER INSERT ON events
  FOR EACH ROW
  EXECUTE FUNCTION notify_new_event();

docs.title: Smart Contracts
docs.text: The Clout Cards smart contract handles all on-chain asset management.

docs.title: Contract Overview
docs.text: Item Value Network Base Sepolia Contract CloutCards (Upgradeable Proxy) Standard ERC-1967 Proxy Pattern

docs.title: Deposits
docs.text:
function deposit() external payable
  • Accepts ETH and credits the sender's escrow balance
  • Emits Deposited(address indexed player, uint256 amount)
  • No minimum deposit required

docs.title: Withdrawals
docs.text:
function withdraw(
    address to,
    uint256 amount,
    uint256 nonce,
    uint256 expiry,
    uint8 v,
    bytes32 r,
    bytes32 s
) external
  • Requires server signature (prevents unauthorized withdrawals)
  • Signature includes nonce and expiry for security
  • Transfers ETH to the specified address

docs.title: Escrow Balance
docs.text:
Each player has an escrow balance tracked on-chain:

mapping(address => uint256) public escrowBalances;
  • Increased by deposits
  • Decreased by withdrawals
  • Game winnings/losses are handled off-chain, then settled via withdrawals

docs.title: Events
docs.text: Event Parameters Description Deposited player, amount ETH deposited to escrow Withdrawn player, to, amount ETH withdrawn from escrow

docs.title: Signature Verification
docs.text:
• Withdrawals require EIP-712 typed signatures
  • Server signs with TEE private key
  • Prevents unauthorized withdrawals

docs.title: Nonce System
docs.text:
• Each withdrawal has a unique nonce
  • Prevents replay attacks
  • Tracked per-player

docs.title: Expiry
docs.text:
• Signatures expire after a set time
  • Prevents stale withdrawal requests
  • Currently: 5 minutes

docs.title: Upgradeability
docs.text:
The contract uses the ERC-1967 proxy pattern:

  • Proxy Contract: Holds state and delegates calls
  • Implementation: Contains logic, can be upgraded
  • Admin: Can upgrade implementation (multisig recommended)

Upgrade Risks

Contract upgrades should be carefully reviewed and tested. State corruption is possible if not handled correctly.

docs.title: EigenCloud TEE
docs.text: Clout Cards runs inside a Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) to provide cryptographic guarantees that the game logic is executed correctly and cannot be tampered with.

docs.title: What is a TEE?
docs.text:
A Trusted Execution Environment is a secure, isolated area of a processor that guarantees:

  • Confidentiality: Data inside the enclave cannot be read by anyone, including the server operator
  • Integrity: Code running inside cannot be modified
  • Attestation: The enclave can prove what code it's running

docs.title: Google Confidential Spaces
docs.text:
Clout Cards is deployed on Google Confidential Spaces, which provides:

Feature Description Hardware-backed isolation AMD SEV-SNP secure processor technology Memory encryption All enclave memory is encrypted Remote attestation Cryptographic proof of enclave integrity No operator access Even Google cannot access enclave data

docs.title: Key Properties
docs.text:
1. Generated inside the enclave - The private key is created when the TEE starts and never exists outside
  2. Never exported - There is no mechanism to extract the key
  3. Deterministic derivation - The same enclave code always produces the same key (via attestation-bound derivation)

docs.title: What Gets Signed
docs.text: Every significant action is signed by the TEE private key using EIP-712 typed signatures:

docs.title: Game Events
docs.text: Event Type Signed Data hand_start Table, players, blinds, dealer position hand_action Action type, amount, player, hand state hand_end Winners, pot distribution, final hands join_table Player, seat, buy-in amount leave_table Player, seat, balance returned

docs.title: Withdrawal Authorizations
docs.text: Field Description Player address Who can withdraw Amount How much (in gwei) Nonce Unique per withdrawal Expiry When signature expires

docs.title: Verification
docs.text: Anyone can verify that data was processed inside the TEE:

docs.title: 1. Get the TEE Public Key
docs.text:
The TEE's public key is derived from the private key and can be retrieved:

GET /teePublicKey

docs.title: 2. Verify Event Signatures
docs.text:
Each event in the database contains:

{
  "eventId": 1234,
  "kind": "hand_action",
  "payloadJson": "{...}",
  "digest": "0x...",
  "sigR": "0x...",
  "sigS": "0x...",
  "sigV": 27,
  "teePubkey": "0x..."
}

Verify by: 1. Compute EIP-712 digest from payloadJson 2. Recover signer from (sigR, sigS, sigV) 3. Confirm recovered address matches teePubkey

docs.title: 3. Verify Attestation
docs.text: Google Confidential Spaces provides attestation that proves: - The exact code running in the enclave - The enclave's integrity - The binding between the code and the TEE public key

docs.title: Security Guarantees
docs.text: Guarantee How It's Achieved Game logic integrity Code runs in attested TEE No card manipulation RNG and dealing inside enclave Withdrawal security Only TEE can sign valid withdrawals Audit trail All events signed and verifiable Operator honesty Operator cannot forge signatures

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
Without the TEE:

  • The server operator could manipulate game outcomes
  • Withdrawal signatures could be forged
  • There would be no proof that the game was fair

With the TEE:

  • Provably fair - Every action is signed by tamper-proof code
  • Trustless - You don't need to trust the operator
  • Verifiable - Anyone can verify the signatures match the TEE
  • Secure - Private key cannot be extracted, even by the operator

docs.title: EigenCloud Integration
docs.text:
Clout Cards uses EigenCloud for TEE deployment and management:

  • Simplified deployment to Google Confidential Spaces
  • Key management and attestation services
  • Monitoring and logging (without exposing sensitive data)

The combination of EigenCloud + Google Confidential Spaces provides enterprise-grade security for trustless game execution.

docs.title: How To Play
docs.text: This section covers everything you need to know to start playing Clout Cards.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you can play, you'll need:

  1. A Web3 wallet (MetaMask recommended)
  2. A Twitter account for identity verification
  3. Some ETH on Base Sepolia for deposits

docs.title: Steps to Get Started
docs.text: Step Description 1. Getting Started Connect your wallet and Twitter account 2. Depositing Funds Add ETH to your escrow balance 3. Joining a Table Find a table and buy in 4. Playing Poker Learn the game flow and actions 5. Withdrawing Funds Cash out your winnings

docs.title: Quick Overview
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Connect Wallet] --> B[Sign in with Twitter]
    B --> C[Deposit ETH]
    C --> D[Join Table]
    D --> E[Play Poker]

docs.title: Depositing Funds
docs.text: Before you can join a table, you need to deposit ETH into your escrow balance.

docs.title: How Deposits Work
docs.text:
1. You send ETH to the Clout Cards smart contract
  2. The contract credits your escrow balance
  3. You can use your escrow balance to buy in at any table
  4. Your escrow balance is tracked on-chain

docs.title: Making a Deposit
docs.text:
1. Go to your Profile page
  2. Click the "Deposit" button
  3. Enter the amount of ETH you want to deposit
  4. Click "Deposit" and confirm the transaction in your wallet

Transaction Confirmation

After submitting, wait for the transaction to be confirmed on Base Sepolia. Your balance will update automatically once confirmed.

docs.title: Deposit Limits
docs.text: Limit Amount Minimum 0.001 ETH Maximum No limit

docs.title: Understanding Your Balance
docs.text:
Your escrow balance is separate from your table balance:

  • Escrow Balance: Funds held in the smart contract, available for buying into tables
  • Table Balance: Funds currently at a poker table (your chip stack)

When you stand up from a table, your table balance is returned to your escrow balance.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will walk you through connecting your wallet and Twitter account to Clout Cards.

docs.title: Step 1: Connect Your Wallet
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Clout Cards
  2. Click the "Sign In" button in the header
  3. Select "Connect Wallet"
  4. Approve the connection in your wallet (MetaMask, etc.)

Network Required

Clout Cards runs on Base Sepolia testnet. Your wallet will be prompted to switch networks if needed.

docs.title: Step 2: Sign the Session Message
docs.text:
After connecting your wallet, you'll be asked to sign a message to create a session:

  1. A signature request will appear in your wallet
  2. Review the message (it contains a timestamp for security)
  3. Click "Sign" to approve

This is NOT a transaction

Signing the session message does not cost any gas or transfer any funds. It simply proves you own the wallet.

docs.title: Step 3: Connect Twitter
docs.text:
1. Click "Connect Twitter"
  2. You'll be redirected to Twitter's authorization page
  3. Review the permissions and click "Authorize app"
  4. You'll be redirected back to Clout Cards

docs.title: You're Ready!
docs.text:
Once both your wallet and Twitter are connected, you'll see your Twitter profile picture and username in the header. You're now fully logged in and can:

  • Deposit funds
  • Join tables
  • Chat with other players
  • Play poker!

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Deposit some funds →

docs.title: Joining a Table
docs.text: Once you have funds in your escrow balance, you can join a poker table.

docs.title: Finding a Table
docs.text:
1. Click "Tables" in the navigation or go to /play
  2. Browse the available tables
  3. Each table shows:
    • Table name
    • Blinds (small/big blind amounts)
    • Buy-in range (minimum/maximum)
    • Number of seats
    • Twitter identities of players currently seated

docs.title: Selecting a Seat
docs.text:
1. Click on a table to enter the table view
  2. Empty seats show a "Buy In" button
  3. Click on an empty seat to join

docs.title: Buying In
docs.text:
When you click an empty seat:

  1. A buy-in dialog appears
  2. Use the slider or input to select your buy-in amount
  3. The amount must be between the table's min and max buy-in
  4. Click "Buy In" to confirm

Buy-in comes from escrow

Your buy-in is deducted from your escrow balance, not your wallet directly.

docs.title: Table Buy-in Ranges
docs.text:
Each table has different buy-in requirements:

Table Type Min Buy-in Max Buy-in Blinds Micro 0.001 ETH 0.01 ETH 0.00001/0.00002 Low 0.01 ETH 0.1 ETH 0.0001/0.0002 Medium 0.1 ETH 1 ETH 0.001/0.002

docs.title: Standing Up
docs.text:
To leave a table:

  1. Wait for the current hand to complete (if in a hand)
  2. Click the "Stand Up" button on your seat
  3. Confirm the action
  4. Your table balance returns to your escrow

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Learn how to play poker →

docs.title: Playing Poker
docs.text: Clout Cards uses standard Texas Hold'em rules. This guide covers the game flow and available actions.

docs.title: 1. Blinds
docs.text:
• The player to the left of the dealer posts the small blind
  • The next player posts the big blind
  • Blinds rotate clockwise each hand

docs.title: 2. Hole Cards
docs.text:
• Each player receives 2 private cards (hole cards)
  • Only you can see your hole cards

docs.title: 3. Betting Rounds
docs.text: Round Community Cards Description Pre-flop None Betting after receiving hole cards Flop 3 cards First 3 community cards revealed Turn 4 cards Fourth community card revealed River 5 cards Fifth and final community card

docs.title: 4. Showdown
docs.text:
• If multiple players remain after the river, cards are revealed
  • Best 5-card hand wins the pot
  • If only one player remains (others folded), they win automatically

docs.title: Available Actions
docs.text:
When it's your turn, you'll see action buttons:

Action When Available Description Fold Always Discard your hand and forfeit the pot Check No bet to call Pass action without betting Call Bet to match Match the current bet Bet No current bet Make the first bet Raise Bet to match Increase the current bet All-In Always Bet all your remaining chips

docs.title: Action Timer
docs.text:
Time Limit

You have 30 seconds to act when it's your turn. If time expires, you'll automatically fold.

docs.title: Hand Rankings
docs.text:
From highest to lowest:

  1. Royal Flush - A, K, Q, J, 10 of same suit
  2. Straight Flush - 5 consecutive cards of same suit
  3. Four of a Kind - 4 cards of same rank
  4. Full House - 3 of a kind + pair
  5. Flush - 5 cards of same suit
  6. Straight - 5 consecutive cards
  7. Three of a Kind - 3 cards of same rank
  8. Two Pair - 2 different pairs
  9. One Pair - 2 cards of same rank
  10. High Card - Highest card wins

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Learn how to withdraw your winnings →

docs.title: Withdrawing Funds
docs.text: When you're ready to cash out, you can withdraw your escrow balance back to your wallet.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before withdrawing:

  1. Stand up from any tables - Your table balance must be returned to escrow
  2. Have a positive escrow balance - Nothing to withdraw if balance is zero

docs.title: How Withdrawals Work
docs.text:
1. You request a withdrawal through the app
  2. The server signs an authorization message
  3. You submit the signed withdrawal to the smart contract
  4. The contract transfers ETH to your wallet

docs.title: Making a Withdrawal
docs.text:
1. Go to your Profile page
  2. Click the "Cash Out" button
  3. Enter the amount you want to withdraw
  4. Click "Withdraw"
  5. Confirm the transaction in your wallet

Gas Fees

Withdrawals require a blockchain transaction, so you'll pay gas fees from your wallet (not your escrow balance).

docs.title: Withdrawal Limits
docs.text: Limit Amount Minimum 0.0001 ETH Maximum Your full escrow balance

docs.title: Withdrawal Security
docs.text:
Withdrawals use a signed message system for security:

  • Each withdrawal request gets a unique nonce
  • The server signs the withdrawal authorization
  • The signature expires after a short time
  • Only you can execute the withdrawal (your wallet)

One at a time

You can only have one pending withdrawal at a time. Complete or let the current one expire before requesting another.

docs.title: Transaction Times
docs.text: Network Confirmation Time Base Sepolia ~2-5 seconds

docs.title: "Withdrawal pending"
docs.text: You already have a pending withdrawal. Wait for it to complete or expire.

docs.title: "Insufficient balance"
docs.text: Your escrow balance is less than the requested amount. Check if you have funds at a table.

docs.title: Transaction failed
docs.text: Check that you have enough ETH in your wallet for gas fees.
